output.conclusion: This course provides an expert-level understanding of Digital Signal Processing, equipping you with the knowledge and skills to tackle complex signal processing challenges in various domains.
output.courseTitle: Digital Signal Processing: Advanced Techniques and Applications
output.introduction: Welcome to the advanced Digital Signal Processing course! This course delves into sophisticated DSP techniques, building upon foundational knowledge to address real-world signal processing problems. We will explore advanced filtering, spectral estimation, adaptive signal processing, and multi-rate signal processing, emphasizing practical applications and implementation considerations.

chapters.description: Explore advanced FIR and IIR filter design methods, including Parks-McClellan algorithm, frequency transformations, and optimization techniques for meeting stringent filter specifications.

Delve into the theory and design of multirate filter banks, including perfect reconstruction filter banks, quadrature mirror filters (QMF), and wavelet transforms for efficient signal decomposition and reconstruction.
Understand the principles and design of fractional delay filters, enabling precise time alignment and interpolation of signals in various applications.
Study parametric spectral estimation methods, such as AR, MA, and ARMA models, for high-resolution spectral analysis and signal parameter estimation.
Explore subspace-based spectral estimation techniques, including MUSIC and ESPRIT algorithms, for detecting and estimating the frequencies of multiple signals in noise.
Investigate time-frequency analysis methods, such as the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) and wavelet transform, for analyzing non-stationary signals and extracting time-varying spectral features.
Study advanced adaptive filtering algorithms, such as Recursive Least Squares (RLS) and Kalman filtering, for tracking time-varying signals and mitigating noise and interference.
Explore adaptive beamforming techniques for spatial filtering and signal enhancement in array processing applications, including minimum variance distortionless response (MVDR) beamforming.
Understand the principles and algorithms for blind source separation (BSS), enabling the recovery of independent source signals from their mixtures without prior knowledge of the mixing process.
